text:
Adopting the cloud will bring
many new capabilities
to your organization.

At AWS, we’re continually
expanding our services to be able

to support virtually any cloud
workload.

We now offer over 200 fully
featured services, including

compute, storage, database,
machine learning, artificial
intelligence, and much more.

The new capabilities
that you gain by using the cloud

can transform how you use technology
within your organization.

But fully realizing these benefits
requires you to re-evaluate

your existing IT operating
model.

If you bring your on-premises
policies and procedures

to the cloud, you’ll miss out
on many of the benefits.

One example of this is storage
capacity management.

Many IT organizations
have a policy of not allowing

their storage utilization  
to exceed 70 or 80 percent.

For them, the additional
expense of overprovisioning

storage is necessary when operating
on premises because IT teams

need time to procure and install
new storage devices in order

to reduce the risk of service
disruptions if they were to run
out of space.

But in the cloud, this type
of overprovisioning

is no longer necessary
because you can now add capacity
to storage volumes instantaneously.

So instead of running 20 to 30
percent above capacity,

you could, for example,
run at 5 percent.

This would still provide
a wide enough safety net, even

if you’ve chosen to continue 
to manage capacity manually.

Or, you could choose to automate
capacity management altogether,

and set up processes to monitor
your volumes and add space
automatically when needed.

In this case, you could safely
run volumes with less than 1 percent

of overhead, if you chose to do
so.

This strategy alone would yield
a 20-plus percent savings

on your storage cost, while
also simplifying operations

by freeing your IT teams from
having to manage capacity
of physical storage arrays.

Automating storage management
also reduces the risk of outages

that often occur when applications
run out of storage.

This is just one example
of how updating your operational

policies can help you take full
advantage of the cloud.

There are many other areas
in which an updated approach

can yield significant
benefits, so take the time to

evaluate your existing policies,
and update them with your new
capabilities in mind.
